snippet.textDisplay: After all these years, all the remakes of this track, this is still the best one. The more complicated and orchestral this track becomes, the more I feel it gets taken away from what it is supposed to represent. Humanity's final, desperate hope. A battle to decide the fate of their world, resting on the shoulders of these four hardened warriors. It's a track that tells a complete story. It cannot be improved upon. It was perfect in 1993, it is perfect now.
snippet.textOriginal: After all these years, all the remakes of this track, this is still the best one. The more complicated and orchestral this track becomes, the more I feel it gets taken away from what it is supposed to represent. Humanity's final, desperate hope. A battle to decide the fate of their world, resting on the shoulders of these four hardened warriors. It's a track that tells a complete story. It cannot be improved upon. It was perfect in 1993, it is perfect now.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Anthony Murano All the more reason why I'm happy that I played the second game first. The Fortress of Doom totally spoils the ending of Rise of the Sinistrals in the first five minutes.

The trade-off being that it left me very disappointed when I finally did play Lufia 1, to the point where I initially hated the game, although I've since grown to like it. Not because I had unreasonably high expectations (it was made earlier, so naturally I expected it to not be as good), but because it didn't deliver in the ways I expected. Most notably, the puzzles. I went into Lufia 1 assuming those were a staple of the series, only to find the first game's dungeons to be generically dull and empty; the most bare-bones dungeons can be. Nor did it have things like capsule monsters, weapon/armor skills, or anything from Lufia 2 that's roots I expected to see in the first game.
snippet.textOriginal:
@Anthony Murano All the more reason why I'm happy that I played the second game first. The Fortress of Doom totally spoils the ending of Rise of the Sinistrals in the first five minutes.

The trade-off being that it left me very disappointed when I finally did play Lufia 1, to the point where I initially hated the game, although I've since grown to like it. Not because I had unreasonably high expectations (it was made earlier, so naturally I expected it to not be as good), but because it didn't deliver in the ways I expected. Most notably, the puzzles. I went into Lufia 1 assuming those were a staple of the series, only to find the first game's dungeons to be generically dull and empty; the most bare-bones dungeons can be. Nor did it have things like capsule monsters, weapon/armor skills, or anything from Lufia 2 that's roots I expected to see in the first game.

I'm glad I got to play the original Lufia on the SNES.  It was so awesome starting with Maxim and his pals, right before the 'final battle'  Great way to make an impact on an RPG.  Fortress of Doom and the Sinistrial Battle are one of the BEST RPG themes imo.

I'm glad I got to play the original Lufia on the SNES.  It was so awesome starting with Maxim and his pals, right before the 'final battle'  Great way to make an impact on an RPG.  Fortress of Doom and the Sinistrial Battle are one of the BEST RPG themes imo.

snippet.textDisplay: @Anthony Murano: It was a terrible remake for many Lufia fans. Natsume dropped the ball on it majorly with all the changes made, and it bombed badly. It's fine if you like it, but the collective longtime fans have voiced their disappointment with it. It was a poor remake for many reasons and watered down too much of the original story while also rewriting quite a few of the characters' personalities (and not necessarily for the better).
snippet.textOriginal: @Anthony Murano: It was a terrible remake for many Lufia fans. Natsume dropped the ball on it majorly with all the changes made, and it bombed badly. It's fine if you like it, but the collective longtime fans have voiced their disappointment with it. It was a poor remake for many reasons and watered down too much of the original story while also rewriting quite a few of the characters' personalities (and not necessarily for the better).

snippet.textDisplay:
@***** And? It's still HORRIBLE. WAY too short, cuts out a lot of the story elements and has that stupid modern gaming design flaw of having to make every character look like it came from the FF7 universe. Estopolis II should have been more medieval like the original, not some half assed medieval yet futuristic crap.


Also, making Guy a dumbass with a sword is DEFINITELY not faithful to the original.

snippet.textDisplay: A "Battery Back-up System" is the internal battery that allows you to save games on an SNES, GB, GBC, GBA, GameGear, SEGA, etc Cartridge. It keeps and maintains all the save files, highscores etc. if it dies however, you will lose all your save files and high scores, and will be unable to save until you replace the battery.
snippet.textOriginal: A "Battery Back-up System" is the internal battery that allows you to save games on an SNES, GB, GBC, GBA, GameGear, SEGA, etc Cartridge. It keeps and maintains all the save files, highscores etc. if it dies however, you will lose all your save files and high scores, and will be unable to save until you replace the battery.

snippet.textDisplay: If they ever made a new sequel to lufia, what would your thoughts be about it taking place in present time? The sinistrals are reborn and the fortress of doom rises from the ocean by a major city. And once again, a descendant of Maxim sets out to rid of them once and for all.
snippet.textOriginal: If they ever made a new sequel to lufia, what would your thoughts be about it taking place in present time? The sinistrals are reborn and the fortress of doom rises from the ocean by a major city. And once again, a descendant of Maxim sets out to rid of them once and for all.

snippet.textDisplay: There's no reason for it to take place in the modern day. It works for Persona because Persona makes use of its setting to do things that are more natural with that setting. You can't just slap a modern setting on anything and expect it to stick. It's two-dimensional thinking.
snippet.textOriginal: There's no reason for it to take place in the modern day. It works for Persona because Persona makes use of its setting to do things that are more natural with that setting. You can't just slap a modern setting on anything and expect it to stick. It's two-dimensional thinking.

Yah...they are all super beings afterall. Good or Evil is irrelavent to that fact and only human made perceptions, much like Daos was trying to explain to Maxim in Lufia 2. Erim is the only super being that realized this fully unfortunately, oh and maybe Sir Arek.

I'd assume Maxim woulda even lived longer than Selan & Guy since he was the 'chosen one'. They were all about 20's..Lufia's generation was younger (16-17) making them like 110-120.

snippet.textDisplay:
The consept of 'Jeros' wasn't created till the Lufia II but it's obvious the main hero isn't Jeros either since it's 99 years in the future, thus it's likely Jeros' son..how else would he be a decadant of Maxim? I don't think it was intended to be overly complicated since we never hear of the females besides Selan in the bloodline (Maxim nor heros mom).

Also Bloodlines don't get 'stronger' as it gets passed down, they become weaker. It's the same consept as taking pieces from a pie.
snippet.textOriginal:
The consept of 'Jeros' wasn't created till the Lufia II but it's obvious the main hero isn't Jeros either since it's 99 years in the future, thus it's likely Jeros' son..how else would he be a decadant of Maxim? I don't think it was intended to be overly complicated since we never hear of the females besides Selan in the bloodline (Maxim nor heros mom).

Also Bloodlines don't get 'stronger' as it gets passed down, they become weaker. It's the same consept as taking pieces from a pie.

snippet.textDisplay: Yah but because IMO Lufia II kills Lufia - playing Lufia II first makes you appreciate Lufia even though LufiaII is the superior game. Plus if you play Lufia I first there's no surprises for the better game (well when it comes to Sinistrals..still surprises but yanno). Erim doesn't become predictable till the 3rd one so either way there are surprises..I see your point about the prologue too but when you play II THEN I it's like your continuing your adventure..very badass.

snippet.textDisplay: Actually I played Lufia II first then Lufia and sure glad I did, it made the experience 100x better IMO. That's what a good prequel does.
snippet.textOriginal: Actually I played Lufia II first then Lufia and sure glad I did, it made the experience 100x better IMO. That's what a good prequel does.

snippet.textDisplay:
The developers made Lufia 2 after everyone played the first one. They did a great job with it as far as making it seem like you're experiencing it for the first time as you play. Knowing what's going to happen (or at least part of what's going to happen, as the game continues after the part shown in Lufia 1 ends) does not ruin the experience at all. 

The added blast of nostalgia starting when the party enters Doom Island really helps.
snippet.textOriginal:
The developers made Lufia 2 after everyone played the first one. They did a great job with it as far as making it seem like you're experiencing it for the first time as you play. Knowing what's going to happen (or at least part of what's going to happen, as the game continues after the part shown in Lufia 1 ends) does not ruin the experience at all. 

The added blast of nostalgia starting when the party enters Doom Island really helps.

A vast new RPG world!

Includes battery-backup system!

epic lulz

snippet.textDisplay: Great, but, plz, Never play lufia 1 before lufia 2; it fuxxing spoils the ENDING, and, believe me, that is one horrible thing to happen.
snippet.textOriginal: Great, but, plz, Never play lufia 1 before lufia 2; it fuxxing spoils the ENDING, and, believe me, that is one horrible thing to happen.

snippet.textDisplay: Yeah, it's an epic moment, cause you know shit's about to go down, and you have a feeling there's no way out, just forward and own those sinistrals!
snippet.textOriginal: Yeah, it's an epic moment, cause you know shit's about to go down, and you have a feeling there's no way out, just forward and own those sinistrals!

snippet.textDisplay: This is the first song you hear in Lufia, after the intro sequence. It got me hooked right away! One of the best dungeon music ever made!
snippet.textOriginal: This is the first song you hear in Lufia, after the intro sequence. It got me hooked right away! One of the best dungeon music ever made!

snippet.textDisplay: Wow another coincidence. I just started uploading lufia videos o.o and yeah to JZA1981 and any other confused players, when you begin a new game the intro begins and you play as Maxim, Selan, etc. in their own final battle.
snippet.textOriginal: Wow another coincidence. I just started uploading lufia videos o.o and yeah to JZA1981 and any other confused players, when you begin a new game the intro begins and you play as Maxim, Selan, etc. in their own final battle.
